channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: U.S. Death Toll, Highest in World, Surpasses 100,000
item.description: Scientists are revising the timeline of how the virus spread. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said she would direct public school districts to share federal aid with private schools.
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angelli Gonzalez and her family visited the grave of her mother, Maria Gonzalez, at St. Peter’s Cemetery in Staten Island on Sunday. Maria Gonzalez died last month of Covid-19.

item.title: Scattered to the Winds, College Students Mourn Lost Semester
item.description: The unpredictability of life during the pandemic has been hard on everyone, but it has caused particular stress for many college students.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maite Rodriguez inside her home, above her family’s restaurant, Maite Sports Bar and Pub, in Newark.

item.title: An ‘Avalanche of Evictions’ Could Be Bearing Down on America’s Renters
item.description: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandy Naffah in her apartment in Euclid, Ohio, with her dog, Shadow. Ms. Naffah is worried about eviction after losing two part-time jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: George Floyd Video and Other Bystander Footage Are Policing the Police
item.description: The initial police account of the death of a Minneapolis man did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Flores/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A memorial in Minneapolis for George Floyd, who died after being taken into custody by the police. A bystander’s video shared widely on Tuesday showed an officer pressing his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.

item.title: Julián Castro: ‘It’s a Totally Porous Safety Net’
item.description: The former presidential candidate on lessons from the pandemic, his next moves and why Joe Biden needs Latino voters.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina

item.title: QuarantineChat Brings Back Spontaneity (and Distraction)
item.description: Phone calls with strangers can reintroduce random connections into our locked-down lives, and be a balm for loneliness and grief.
item.dc:creator: Devi Lockwood
item.media:description: Danielle Baskin, who founded QuarantineChat with Max Hawkins. The app randomly connects people around the world. Baskin said she hoped the calls would “kindle unexpected friendships.”

item.title: Rosenstein to Testify on Russia Inquiry to Panel Led by Trump Ally
item.description: The former deputy attorney general was a key part of the investigation. The hearing will also give Trump allies a prominent platform to attack it.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rod J. Rosenstein, the former deputy attorney general, appointed Robert S. Mueller III as special counsel to investigate Russia’s 2016 election interference.

item.title: House Passes Uighur Human Rights Bill, Prodding Trump to Punish China
item.description: The House overwhelmingly cleared legislation that would punish top Chinese officials for detaining more than one million Muslims in internment camps.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Uighur men at a mosque in China’s Xinjiang region last year.

item.title: Twitter Comes Under Attack From Trump’s Supporters
item.description: After the social media company labeled two of the president’s tweets as inaccurate on Tuesday, his adherents pounced.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Davey Alba
item.media:description: The backlash against Twitter came from a variety of sources: elected officials, conservative websites, pundits and individuals.

item.title: ‘Just Sitting in Limbo.’ For Many Professionals, Careers Are on Hold.
item.description: Even for well-connected high earners, hiring has dried up, advancement has ceased, job searches have paused and new ventures are in jeopardy.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m mostly having Zoom calls with strangers,” said Hasti Nazem, who left her job just before the shutdown.

item.title: Tropical Storm Bertha Could Cause Dangerous Flooding in the South
item.description: Bertha was named a tropical storm less than two hours before it made landfall near Charleston, S.C., on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: States Sue to Block Trump From Weakening Fuel Economy Rules
item.description: At stake in the lawsuit is the single biggest effort by the United States to fight the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morning traffic on Highway 580 near Livermore, Calif. The state is leading a coalition in the lawsuit.

item.title: Coronavirus Epidemics Began Later Than Believed, Study Concludes
item.description: In Washington State and Italy, the first confirmed cases were not linked to the outbreaks that followed, the analysis found. The epidemics were seeded later.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A library of coronavirus samples for gene sequencing at a University of Washington lab last month.

item.title: Activists and Celebrities Honor Larry Kramer’s Brash Advocacy
item.description: Mr. Kramer, who died on Wednesday, was remembered for his pioneering and often confrontational work during the early days of the AIDS crisis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: An illustration of Larry Kramer in his Manhattan apartment.

item.title: Ravi Zacharias, Preacher Who Used Reason to Defend Faith, Dies at 74
item.description: The influential evangelist sought to “connect the gospel with the life of the mind.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz

item.title: Coronavirus Isn’t Keeping Florida Crowds From SpaceX Launch
item.description: Many beachside hotels along the state’s Space Coast were already at capacity before Wednesday’s scheduled launch, a local tourism executive said.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.media:description: Early risers in Titusville, Fla., claimed spots to watch the launch on Wednesday.

item.title: Disney World is Reopening, but You Won’t Be Able to Hug Mickey
item.description: The Florida resort is one of the largest tourist sites in the world, but capacity will be limited, face masks will be mandatory, and it won’t be possible to get up close and personal with characters.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Eve Edelheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Magic Kingdom in Florida, the world’s No. 1 theme park by attendance, will reopen on a limited basis on July 11.

item.title: Hong Kong Has Lost Autonomy, Pompeo Says, Opening Door to U.S. Action
item.description: The State Department announcement comes as President Trump weighs hard measures against China, which is expected to approve a national security law on Hong Kong on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: “No reasonable person can assert today that Hong Kong maintains a high degree of autonomy from China, given facts on the ground,” Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said.

item.title: SpaceX Launch: Highlights From the Weather-Delayed Mission
item.description: Follow SpaceX's launch of NASA astronauts aboard the Crew Dragon spacecraft.
item.media:description: Ominous clouds over the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket and Crew Dragon Spacecraft at Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Wednesday.

item.title: Larry Kramer, Playwright and Outspoken AIDS Activist, Dies at 84
item.description: He sought to shock the country into dealing with AIDS as a public-health emergency and foresaw that it could kill millions regardless of sexual orientation.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Lewis
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Mr. Kramer at home in 1989, a year after he learned he was H.I.V. positive.

item.title: Lyme Disease Season Is Here. These Are Tips on How to Avoid It.
item.description: The basic symptoms mirror Covid-19, and that’s a worry nobody needs. Plus, a serious illness like Lyme could put you at greater risk from Covid.
item.dc:creator: Zoë Schlanger
item.media:description: A hiking trail in the Cape Cod National Seashore in Massachusetts.

item.title: The Death of George Floyd in Minneapolis: What We Know So Far
item.description: Mr. Floyd died after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by an officer’s knee, in an episode that was recorded on video by a bystander, inciting condemnation and protests.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Pride and Panic: Children of Health Care Workers Grapple With Pandemic
item.description: Children whose parents work on the front lines of the coronavirus outbreak worry about jobs they say are important but hazardous.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Heather Walsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcela Vasquez with her daughters, Eva Ozario, 4, and Alyssa Barnes, 13. Ms. Vasquez, a phlebotomist at Long Island Community Hospital, tested positive for coronavirus.

item.title: When Will Hair Salons Reopen in California?
item.description: Wednesday: Like many services, it depends on where you live. Also: Testing continues to be a vexing puzzle, as does sheltering with others.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Alex Horvath/The Bakersfield Californian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sandra Serrano, a stylist, colored Norma Beltran's hair at the Atomic Kitten Salon on May 19, in Bakersfield, before stylists and barbers were officially allowed to return to work.

item.title: Big Pharmacy Chains Also Fed the Opioid Epidemic, Court Filing Says
item.description: New details emerge in a lawsuit asserting that chains including CVS, Rite Aid and Walgreens sold millions of pills in small towns but rarely flagged suspicious orders to authorities.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: CVS, which operates thousands of pharmacies, worked with manufacturers to promote opioids as safe and effective, according to a new court filing.

item.title: Trump Plays the Old Conspiracy Theory Hits on Twitter
item.description: Trump smears Joe Scarborough, and Twitter does a voting fact-check: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The Persistence of Police Killings
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jenna Watson/Indianapolis Star, via Associated Press

item.title: When the Mexican Air Force Went to War Alongside America
item.description: In 1945, the 201st Mexican Fighter Squadron helped the U.S. Army Air Forces defeat Japan — significantly changing relations between the two allies after the war.
item.dc:creator: Richard Parker
item.media:description: Members of the 201st Fighter Squadron of the Mexican Expeditionary Air Force, which was attached to the Fifth Air Force during World War II, at Clark Field in the Philippines.

item.title: They Evoke Darth Vader, but These Masks May Save Your Doctor’s Life
item.description: With medical masks in short supply, several hospitals have turned to industrial models. They get rave reviews and are allowed by the F.D.A., but the Trump administration has no plans to encourage distribution or production.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hamby
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times

item.title: Meet Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley, SpaceX’s First NASA Astronauts
item.description: They’re best friends and veterans of the astronaut corps, and each is married to another astronaut.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The astronauts Robert L. Behnken, left, and Douglas G. Hurley, donning their spacesuits during a dress rehearsal of SpaceX’s uncrewed In-Flight Abort Test in January.

item.title: Despite Racist Remarks, Steve King Might Win Tuesday’s Iowa Primary
item.description: The congressman has been an outcast among mainstream Republicans ever since he suggested that white nationalism was not offensive. But his four primary challengers could split the vote next week.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Representative Steve King of Iowa was removed from his committee assignments after he told The New York Times, “White nationalist, white supremacist, Western civilization — how did that language become offensive?”

item.title: Stock Market: Live News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange in Wall Street in New York during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Live World Updates on the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: As concerns about a much-touted Covid-19 drug grow, France has revoked its authorization as a treatment. In China, the rise of virus-tracking apps is stirring privacy fears.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunrise in Milan. Italy would get the most aid under a proposed E.U. stimulus package .

item.title: SpaceX Astronaut Launch Postponed to Saturday
item.description: What you need to know about the mission taking two NASA astronauts to the space station on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A SpaceX rocket with the Crew Dragon capsule on top as it was raised onto the launchpad on Tuesday at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

item.title: Michigan Governor Says Husband’s Request Was ‘Failed Attempt at Humor’
item.description: A business owner said Marc Mallory had pointed out that he was married to Gov. Gretchen Whitmer while asking if the company could move his boat sooner.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in Midland, Mich., this month.

item.title: Jimmy Fallon Apologizes for Blackface Skit
item.description: In a ‘Saturday Night Live’ sketch from 2000, Mr. Fallon appears in blackface while impersonating his fellow comedian Chris Rock.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Fallon in February. “There is no excuse for this,” Mr. Fallon said of the blackface sketch.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: For some Americans, the biggest concern is the threat they feel from other people’s irresponsible behavior.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Will Twitter Draw a Line for Trump?
item.description: Kara Swisher says President Trump is an expert at gaming Twitter, but the company can still step in.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
